content: The Act titled "Government Employee Accountability Act" allows for the suspension of Senior Executive Service employees for 14 days or less. The Act titled "Government Employee Accountability Act" allows for the suspension of Senior Executive Service employees for 14 days or less. Paragraph (1) of section 7501 of title 5, United States Code, is amended to define an "employee" as an individual in the competitive service or a career appointee in the Senior Executive Service. The Act allows for the suspension of Senior Executive Service employees for 14 days or less. SEC. 3. INVESTIGATIVE LEAVE AND TERMINATION AUTHORITY FOR SENIOR EXECUTIVE SERVICE EMPLOYEES. Amends Chapter 75 of title 5, United States Code to include a new subchapter on investigative leave for Senior Executive Service employees. Sec. 7551 defines 'employee' and 'investigative leave'. Sec. 7552 applies to investigative leave. Sec. 7553 outlines the cause and procedure for placing an employee on investigative leave for misconduct or other specified reasons. During investigative leave for misconduct, an agency can place an employee without pay. The agency must review the investigation every 45 days and report to relevant committees. At the end of the leave, the agency must remove the employee. An agency can remove, suspend without pay, or reinstate an employee on investigative leave. The agency can extend the leave for up to 90 days. Before placing an employee on leave, they must provide at least 30 days' notice with specific reasons, unless there is reasonable cause to believe a crime has been committed. An agency can remove, suspend without pay, or reinstate an employee on investigative leave. The employee must be given a reasonable time to respond, be represented by an attorney, and receive a written decision with specific reasons. The agency may also provide for a hearing as part of the process. An employee can appeal to the Merit Systems Protection Board if action is taken against them. The agency must maintain and provide relevant documents to the Board and the affected employee upon request. "SUBCHAPTER VII--REMOVAL OF SENIOR EXECUTIVE SERVICE EMPLOYEES" "Sec. 7562 allows agency heads to remove employees for neglect of duty, misappropriation of funds, or malfeasance if it endangers agency interests and is necessary for the United States." An employee may not be removed under section 7562 if the removal would violate any laws or if there is an ongoing legal proceeding related to the removal. The employee must be notified of the reasons for removal and has 30 days to submit statements or affidavits to argue for reinstatement. Whenever an employee is removed under this section, the agency head must notify Congress with specific reasons. The employee has the right to appeal to the Merit Systems Protection Board. All relevant documents and supporting materials must be maintained by the agency and provided to the employee. The agency must maintain and provide relevant documents to the Merit Systems Protection Board and the affected employee upon request. A removal under this section does not prevent the employee from seeking employment in other government departments. The authority of the agency head under this section cannot be delegated. Subchapter VI outlines investigative leave for Senior Executive Service employees, including definitions, actions covered, and cause and procedure. Subchapter VII covers the removal of Senior Executive Service employees, defining the process for their removal. Section 4 discusses the suspension of Senior Executive Service employees. Section 7543 of title 5, United States Code, is amended to include provisions for misappropriation of funds and advance written notice for proposed actions against employees, with exceptions for criminal behavior or flagrant misconduct. SEC. 5. MISAPPROPRIATION OF FUNDS AMENDMENTS. Amends Section 3593 of title 5, United States Code, to include "misappropriation of funds" alongside "malfeasance" in the Senior Executive Service reinstatement criteria. Also updates Section 3594(a) to include "misappropriation of funds" as a cause for placement in other personnel systems.
